localizedDescriptions.en: Interaction, contact or care event between a subject of care and healthcare provider(s).
Summary information about the significant health-related problems found in family members.
Narrative overview about problems, diagnoses, psychosocial, environmental and genetic markers that have been identified in family members.

annotations.comment: This field can be used to record a summary or the conclusion of all the findings, for unstructured family history information recorded in clinical records, or to import textual data from existing/legacy clinical systems.

localizedDescriptions.en: A media file that is acquired or used as part of the healthcare process, and associated metadata.
Digital representation of the media file.

annotations.comment: If the file is stored locally, the actual content will be captured and stored using the Multimedia data type. For example: RTF or PDF for a document; JPG for an image; MP4 for a video; or WAV for an audio file. If the file is stored at a location outside of the health record, the detailed path to the file is captured using the URI attribute in the Multimedia data type. The Multimedia data type has many RM attributes such as the size of file and URI to an external source - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_multimedia_class.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date this family history summary was last updated.
Summary information about the significant health-related problems found in family members.
Narrative overview about problems, diagnoses, psychosocial, environmental and genetic markers that have been identified in family members.

annotations.comment: This field can be used to record a summary or the conclusion of all the findings, for unstructured family history information recorded in clinical records, or to import textual data from existing/legacy clinical systems.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about the presence of a specific problem or diagnosis in family members.
Summary information about the prevalence of a risk factor, problem or diagnosis in all family members.
Is there a genetic basis for the identified risk factor, problem or diagnosis?

annotations.comment: Optional to record as True if there is a recognised genetic predisposition. In many cases, this may be inferred from the risk factor, problem or diagnosis and not need to be recorded explicitly.

localizedDescriptions.en: Category of inheritance for the identified risk factor, problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: For example: autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, X-linked dominant, X-linked recessive, codominant, or mitochondrial.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about the numbers of family members affected.
The degree of relationship between the subject of care and a selected group of family members.
50% genetic share with the subject - for example, parent, sibling or child.
25% genetic share with the subject - for example, grandparent, aunt, uncle, niece, nephew, grandchildren and half siblings.
12.5% genetic share with the subject - for example, great grandparent, great aunt, great uncle, first cousin, children of nieces and nephews, and great grandchildren.
All genetically-related family members.
All non-genetic family members.

annotations.comment: This cluster will be repeated for each relationship, family line, sex value or combination of all three. For example, the cluster will be repeated for any or all of first degree relative (without sex specified), first degree relative from maternal line; first degree male relative or first degree female relative; or all males, all females.

If the problem has a genetic predisposition within families, then only genetic relatives should be considered as part of this data. If the problem has psychosocial or environmental effects then non-genetic family members may also be included.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date this family history summary was last updated.
The rate of growth, or change in growth measurements, over a period of time.
A subset of persistent or summary information about the pregnancy and birth of an infant, selected for utility of use within both the maternal and infant health records.
The length of the pregnancy at the time of delivery of the infant.

annotations.comment: The value for this data element will usually, but not always, be identical to the 'Pregnancy duration' data element within the EVALUATION.pregnancy_summary in the maternal record. It may also be derived using the 'Agreed date' data element within the EVALUATION.estimated_date_delivery archetype in the maternal record. Usually estimated by Naegele's rule or by ultrasound scan.

children.name: Current and previous growth charts

annotations.comment: If the file is stored locally, the actual content will be captured and stored using the Multimedia data type. For example: RTF or PDF for a document; JPG for an image; MP4 for a video; or WAV for an audio file. If the file is stored at a location outside of the health record, the detailed path to the file is captured using the URI attribute in the Multimedia data type. The Multimedia data type has many RM attributes such as the size of file and URI to an external source - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_multimedia_class.

children.name: Comment

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the media file not captured in other fields.

children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-OBSERVATION.growth_velocity.v0 and name/value='Growth chart']/protocol[at0010]/items[openEHR-EHR-CLUSTER.media_file.v1 and name/value='Current and previous growth charts']/items[at0007]/value

localizedDescriptions.en: Measurement of the body weight of an individual.

children.name: Weight at the last visit

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.

children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-OBSERVATION.body_weight.v2]/data[at0002]/events[at0003 and name/value='Weight at the last visit']

children.name: Weight

localizedDescriptions.en: The weight of the individual.

children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-OBSERVATION.body_weight.v2]/data[at0002]/events[at0003 and name/value='Weight at the last visit']/data[at0001]/items[at0004]/value

children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-OBSERVATION.body_weight.v2]/data[at0002]/events[at0003 and name/value='Weight at the last visit']/time

localizedDescriptions.en:
Usually the first weight, measured soon after birth. This event will only be used once per health record
.
The weight of the individual.
Height, or body length, is measured from crown of head to sole of foot.

children.name: Length at the last visit

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.

children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-OBSERVATION.height.v2]/data[at0001]/events[at0002 and name/value='Length at the last visit']

children.name: Height/Length

localizedDescriptions.en: The length of the body from crown of head to sole of foot.

children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-OBSERVATION.height.v2]/data[at0001]/events[at0002 and name/value='Length at the last visit']/data[at0003]/items[at0004]/value

children.name: time
children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-OBSERVATION.height.v2]/data[at0001]/events[at0002 and name/value='Length at the last visit']/time

localizedDescriptions.en:
Usually the first length measurement, recorded soon after birth. This event will only be used once per health record
.
The length of the body from crown of head to sole of foot.

annotations.comment: Height is measured with the individual in a standing position and body length in a recumbent position.

localizedDescriptions.en: The measurement of the longest distance around the head.

children.name: Head circumference at the last visit
children.localizedName: Head circumference at the last visit

localizedNames.en: Head circumference at the last visit

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.

children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-OBSERVATION.head_circumference.v1]/data[at0001]/events[at0010 and name/value='Head circumference at the last visit']

children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-OBSERVATION.head_circumference.v1]/data[at0001]/events[at0010 and name/value='Head circumference at the last visit']/data[at0003]/items[at0004]/value

children.name: Confounding factors

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative descripiton of any issues or factors that may impact on the measurement.

children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-OBSERVATION.head_circumference.v1]/data[at0001]/events[at0010 and name/value='Head circumference at the last visit']/state[at0008]/items[at0009]/value

annotations.comment: For example: 'uncooperative child','caput & moulding post birth' and 'haematoma'.

children.name: time
children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-OBSERVATION.head_circumference.v1]/data[at0001]/events[at0010 and name/value='Head circumference at the last visit']/time

localizedDescriptions.en: The first measurement of head circumference that is recorded soon after birth. This event should only be used once per record.
The measurement of the longest distance around the head.
Suggested design pattern for including diagnostic test results in a template.
Record the findings and interpretation of an imaging examination performed.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The name of the imaging examination or procedure performed.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is strongly recommended, preferably a term specifying both modality and anatomical location, where possible. Possible candidate terminologies are LOINC, SNOMED CT or RadLex.

localizedDescriptions.en: Type of equipment that originally acquired the image or series of images.

annotations.comment: Also known as 'Examination type'. For example: Ultrasound; Computed tomography; or X-ray. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible. If the modality is specified by a code in the 'Test name', then this field may be redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: A media file that is acquired or used as part of the healthcare process, and associated metadata.
Digital representation of the media file.

annotations.comment: If the file is stored locally, the actual content will be captured and stored using the Multimedia data type. For example: RTF or PDF for a document; JPG for an image; MP4 for a video; or WAV for an audio file. If the file is stored at a location outside of the health record, the detailed path to the file is captured using the URI attribute in the Multimedia data type. The Multimedia data type has many RM attributes such as the size of file and URI to an external source - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_multimedia_class.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result, including findings and the laboratory's interpretation, of an investigation performed on specimens collected from an individual or related to that individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Name of the laboratory investigation performed on the specimen(s).

annotations.comment: A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. It is strongly recommended that 'Test name' be coded with a terminology, for example LOINC or SNOMED CT. For example: 'Glucose', 'Urea and Electrolytes', 'Swab', 'Cortisol (am)', 'Potassium in perspiration' or 'Melanoma histopathology'. The name may sometimes include specimen type and patient state, for example 'Fasting blood glucose' or include other information, as 'Potassium (PNA blood gas)'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date and/or time that ‘Overall test status’ was issued.
Narrative description of the key findings.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Pattern suggests significant renal impairment'. The content of the conclusion will vary, depending on the investigation performed. This conclusion should be aligned with the coded 'Test diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: A media file that is acquired or used as part of the healthcare process, and associated metadata.
Digital representation of the media file.

annotations.comment: If the file is stored locally, the actual content will be captured and stored using the Multimedia data type. For example: RTF or PDF for a document; JPG for an image; MP4 for a video; or WAV for an audio file. If the file is stored at a location outside of the health record, the detailed path to the file is captured using the URI attribute in the Multimedia data type. The Multimedia data type has many RM attributes such as the size of file and URI to an external source - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_multimedia_class.

localizedDescriptions.en: A local identifier assigned by the receiving Laboratory Information System (LIS) to track the test process.
A local identifier assigned by the receiving Laboratory Information System (LIS) to track the test process.

annotations.comment: This identifier is an internal tracking number assigned by the LIS, and it not intended to be the name of the test.

localizedDescriptions.en: A local identifier assigned by the receiving Laboratory Information System (LIS) to track the test process.

annotations.comment: This identifier is an internal tracking number assigned by the LIS, and it not intended to be the name of the test.
This identifier is an internal tracking number assigned by the LIS, and it not intended to be the name of the test.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about the test request.
Name of the original laboratory test requested.

annotations.comment: This data element is to be used when the test requested differs from the test actually performed by the laboratory.

localizedDescriptions.en: The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.
The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.

annotations.comment: Equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.

localizedDescriptions.en: The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.

annotations.comment: Equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.
Equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.

localizedDescriptions.en: The local identifier assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the Laboratory Information System (LIS).
The local identifier assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the Laboratory Information System (LIS).

annotations.comment: Assigning an identifier to a request by the Laboratory lnformation System (LIS) enables tracking progress of the request and enables linking results to requests. It also provides a reference to assist with enquiries and it is usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.

localizedDescriptions.en: The local identifier assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the Laboratory Information System (LIS).

annotations.comment: Assigning an identifier to a request by the Laboratory lnformation System (LIS) enables tracking progress of the request and enables linking results to requests. It also provides a reference to assist with enquiries and it is usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.

Assigning an identifier to a request by the Laboratory lnformation System (LIS) enables tracking progress of the request and enables linking results to requests. It also provides a reference to assist with enquiries and it is usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.

In most situations there is one test request and a single corresponding test result, however this repeating cluster allows for the situation where there may be multiple test requests reported using a single test result.

As an example: 'a clinician asks for blood glucose in one request and Urea/electrolytes in a second request, but the lab analyser does both and the lab wishes to report these together'.

localizedDescriptions.en: This indicates whether the test was performed directly at Point-of-Care (POCT) as opposed to a formal result from a laboratory or other service delivery organisation.

annotations.comment: True if the test was performed directly at Point-of-Care (POCT).

localizedDescriptions.en: Description about the method used to perform the test.
Description about the method used to perform the test.
Description about the method used to perform the test.
Description about the method used to perform the test.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative summary or overview about a patient, specifically from the perspective of a healthcare provider, and with or without associated interpretations.
The summary, assessment, conclusions or evaluation of the clinical findings.
Narrative summary or overview about a patient, specifically from the perspective of a healthcare provider, and with or without associated interpretations.
The summary, assessment, conclusions or evaluation of the clinical findings.
A subset of persistent or summary information about the pregnancy and birth of an infant, selected for utility of use within both the maternal and infant health records.
Method by which the newborn was delivered.
Normal, non-instrumental vaginal delivery.
Vaginal delivery assisted by maneuvers in the delivery of the remainder of the body, arms, and head.
Vaginal delivery, by which the fetal feet are grasped, and the entire fetus is extracted.
Vaginal delivery assisted by the use of vacuum extraction.
Vaginal delivery assisted by the use of vacuum extraction.
Vaginal delivery assisted by the use of lift-out forceps.
Vaginal delivery assisted by the use of low forceps.
Vaginal delivery assisted by the use of high forceps.
Vaginal delivery assisted by the use of high forceps with rotation.
Surgical delivery by a transverse approach in the lower uterine segment (LUSCS).
Surgical delivery by an approach in the upper uterine segment.

annotations.comment: For example: vaginal; forceps rotation; or Caesarean Section.
